There are 3 particle, mass, electric & magnetic charge. There are also 3 spatial dimensions xyz, 1 for each particle. Electric & magnetic  changes have  opposite counterparts therefore their particles can move in opposite directions of their dimension. Mass has no such opposite counterpart therefore it can move in 1 direction of  its dimension. No physical entity can exist in less or more than 3 dimensions. Therefore for a particle to exist all 3 spatial dimensions must be occupied. Therefore all stable particles must have mass, electric & magnetic charge. To form wave particles must move in opposite directions. Since mass can move in 1 direction it acts as particle while electric & magnetic particles can move in opposite directions they act as waves. All stable particle will always exhibit wave-particle duality.

Sorry about this mistake above...I meant to say that a Wave is what something DOES not what something IS.
She said light is both a particle and a wave... Pay attention and keep up.
@fangus5076  It's not purely a wave. It has wave-particle duality so the title "light is waves" is a misguided claim.
@aapowilen5436  Ok... I hope people are rushed to the extent that they review by just reading the title of crash-course lmao.

@fangus5076  Then after the introduction it is claimed that light is a wave.  Then she goes on and says after referring to the duality, "the point is light is a wave". I understand that the video focuses only on it's wave properties because of the topic. However it's misguiding viewers saying so adamantly and strongly about it's wave behavior. Almost completely dismissing the particle properties which are equally as important.

@aapowilen5436  lol, this entire channel is geared towards high school audience who just use these videos to catch up on things they missed at school. The wave-like properties of light are what is being stressed in that curriculum. If people are more interested in this phenomenon there are much better sources.
@fangus5076  Just because it's intended towards high school audiences doesn't mean you have to dumb it down to the level where it's almost misleading.
@aapowilen5436  I don't think it's misleading... Honestly, what can the general public do with that information? "I know light is both a particle and a wave ; b I'm so smart lol"

@fangus5076  No just don't claim something that is misleading. You don't have to go in depth into it. Just don't say something that is untrue. It's not about being clever or anything. Understanding the duality is probably the most significant thing in modern physics since it lead to the development of quantum mechanics. It's no trivia. As I said in my initial claim: it's an antique view and when emphasized to this extent, it's also misleading.

These videos are amazing, and they’ve totally saved me a handful of times during the mad dash that is summer physics!! I’ve found what works best for me is to watch the video, then read the corresponding textbook chapter, and then watch the video again. The first time watching it, it may not make too much sense. However, after reading the textbook chapter, it’s a super great way to gauge how much you understand and try to get a deeper/more dynamic understanding of the big concepts before moving to working some math problems. Good luck to all of the other physics students out there!!!

Khala6-خلاط Good question. To put it simply, it actually does. However, it is not what one would think. Some may pass through but will not form an image for a person to see as it is nowhere near what the source produced. Light is a particle when observed. So when we want to measure things we are doing it while considering it is a particle. When we leave it  alone, a interference pattern forms just like in the video thus it behaves as a wave. Light does not require a medium but it depends on what you consider mediums. The vacuum of space in my case is not exactly a medium and light travels through it. And to clarify, those microwave cookers use microwaves to cook, WIFI (depends)normally uses microwaves to travel. And now. Photons are light. And all the EM waves are carried by photons cause there are just different energy levels. So one POSSIBLE way to think is that the visible light (you are talking about) is unable to form through a medium as the photons are blocked out by walls and thus the reason why you CAN see the wall. This is possible but then again we are just diving into the world of quantum mechanics. No explanation is correct currently. Suggest you do more research

we are kind of transparent bc don't forget the X-RAYS it can pass threw  Carbon, Nitrogen, Hydrogen, and Oxygen with small amounts of Phosphorous Iron, Sodium, Magnesium, Sulphur, Calcium and Chlorine (SKIN if you didn't get it)  but can't pass threw  Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 (BONES if you didn't get it) so light can pass threw I mean special type of light.

Khala6-خلاط Yeah. Just like how objects emit infrared. Waves pass through different objects but of course reflection and refraction is still difficult to explain as we are still getting into the world of quantum mechanics l

The slit must be equal to or smaller than the wavelength.   So to have the experiment be fair the slit must also be the same size as the ball.   What happens if hole is equal to or smaller than the ball?   A least the slit must be equal in size to the length of the particle.    We know that electrons don't travel in a perfectly straight line.   So why would we expect photons to do so?    In fact if you shoot any light through an aperture larger than the wavelength the light will not form a pattern.  It will behave exactly as if it's particles.

There has been confusion in the comments over photons as particles and light as waves.  Let me point out Richard Feynman's view.  He said, quite firmly, that photons are particles, "lumps".  Then he showed that, for several important circumstances, the mathematics of quantum mechanics produces probability distributions that happen to match, precisely, the intensity distributions predicted by wave theory.  Despite the equations giving equivalent results to wave theory for several circumstances, it is vital to remember that there are also important circumstances for which wave theory gives absolutely wrong predictions.  The first two examples are still among the best, black-body radiation and the photoelectric effect.  These can only be explained quantum mechanically.

If a photon is shortened to a quarter wavelength (in an advanced optics laboratory), what is its total wave-cycle-count length for when it passes through a Young's Double Slit experiment—Does it still show 10± lobes on the photoscreen, or is it fewer lobes, (try it)...

Good question and answered by Austin Tuttle. If the energy of a wave was reduced to zero there would be no further progression of the wave to create further patterns. By the way, sine curve representation of light is misleading. It is a graphical way of describing a vibration over time, not how light actually travels. You will probably ask why is there a dark band despite that "hidden" energy hitting the screen.

Objects described by quantum mechanics are their own category of non-intuitive things, and while they do have properties that remind us of the older, classical paradigms, that doesn't make those paradigms fit for explaining QM.

Force carriers aren't "particles" in the traditional sense, instead they refer to quantities of energy moving through a field. Photons are quantities of energy that move through an electromagnetic field and gravitons are quantities of energy moving through a gravitational field.   For example if you flip a rope, a wave of energy moves through the rope. In an analogy with light, the rope is the medium (the EM field) and the moving wave of energy would literally be light itself.

Buck Turgidson energy is the amount of capability matter and radiation have to perform work. It's analogous to say that everything is actually size instead of matter. The same thing applies to waves, they aren't their own discrete things separate from matter but instead a type of oscillatory motion that spreads outward.

GDI all kinds of bosons, including photons and gravitons, are a part of the standard model, which include physical things that occupy space, can be interacted with and can't be split further.   "instead they refer to quantities of energy moving through a field." You probably aren't aware of this fact, but energy itself is not some discrete thing that can exist by itself. It's the capability of matter to perform work, so it's misleading to say that it's "quantities of energy moving through a field". Energy isn't it's own object anymore than size and shape is.

Double slit experiments are not slits in a 2 dimensional plane. Creating a slit also creates a wall to bounce off.on each side of the slit. It's more like a hallway than a slit. Keep in mind the light is entering into the hallway (slit) at an angle. This may simply be reflecting light.  I propose a cross examination experiment. Mirror coat the interior of the slits. I predict greater brightness lines will occur, if so, disproving the former theory.   For further clarification of where each effect is occurring from, coat only one slit. For greater clarity still, colour the mirrors differently on each face.
